stem: For each finding below, click to specify if the finding indicates possible preeclampsia or possible gestational diabetes.

rationale.correct: Elevated blood pressure and proteinuria are key indicators of preeclampsia. Elevated fasting blood glucose is a key indicator of gestational diabetes. Thrombocytopenia can be associated with preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria (or other signs of end-organ damage) after 20 weeks of gestation. The elevated blood pressure damages the endothelial lining of blood vessels, leading to increased vascular permeability and proteinuria. Thrombocytopenia results from platelet activation and consumption as part of the disease process. Gestational diabetes is diagnosed when glucose intolerance is first recognized during pregnancy, often due to insulin resistance caused by placental hormones. A fasting blood glucose level of 145 mg/dL exceeds the normal range for pregnant women, indicating impaired glucose metabolism.

mnemonic.name: HELLP Syndrome
mnemonic.application: This mnemonic helps recall the key lab values to monitor for in patients with preeclampsia.
mnemonic.description: HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count) is a severe complication of preeclampsia. Remember HELLP to assess for potential end-organ damage.

rationale.incorrect: Normal edema and fundal height don't indicate preeclampsia or gestational diabetes. Normal fetal heart tones do not differentiate between preeclampsia and gestational diabetes. Normal deep tendon reflexes don't indicate preeclampsia or gestational diabetes. Mild anemia can be present in pregnancy and is not specific to either condition. Edema is common in pregnancy due to increased blood volume and decreased colloid osmotic pressure. Fundal height and fetal heart tones are general assessments of fetal well-being but do not specifically point to preeclampsia or gestational diabetes. Deep tendon reflexes are assessed to evaluate for hyperreflexia, which is associated with preeclampsia, but normal reflexes do not rule it out. Mild anemia is a common physiological change in pregnancy due to hemodilution.

questionTrap.risk: Tendency to focus solely on one finding (e.g., edema) without considering the overall clinical picture.
questionTrap.mitigation: Emphasize the importance of evaluating multiple clinical findings and considering the patient's medical history.
questionTrap.explanation: Be careful not to assume all pregnant women with edema have preeclampsia. Consider all findings together. Distinguish between chronic hypertension and preeclampsia. Edema alone is not diagnostic; it must be considered in conjunction with other signs and symptoms, such as elevated blood pressure and proteinuria. The patient's history of chronic hypertension further complicates the diagnosis, as it can be difficult to differentiate between chronic hypertension and superimposed preeclampsia.

clinicalPearls: Preeclampsia is a pregnancy-specific condition characterized by hypertension and proteinuria, or other signs of end-organ damage, after 20 weeks gestation.
Gestational diabetes is diagnosed when glucose intolerance is first recognized during pregnancy.
Chronic hypertension can make it difficult to diagnose preeclampsia, therefore new onset proteinuria or worsening hypertension should raise concern for superimposed preeclampsia.
Clinical Pearl: In patients with chronic hypertension, a sudden increase in blood pressure or the development of proteinuria should raise suspicion for superimposed preeclampsia.

itemContext.sbar: 07:00 S: Patient is a 32-year-old female, G2P1 at 28 weeks gestation, presenting for a routine prenatal visit. She has a history of chronic hypertension, well-controlled with medication prior to pregnancy. A: Patient reports occasional headaches but no visual disturbances or epigastric pain. B: Chronic hypertension, well-controlled prior to pregnancy. Medications include labetalol 200mg BID, which she has been taking since 12 weeks gestation. O: Vital signs and lab results are pending review. Fetal heart tones are present and within normal limits. Currently, the patient denies any contractions or vaginal bleeding. The patient is alert and oriented.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
Blood Pressure: 148/92 mmHg
Heart Rate: 88 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/min
Temperature: 98.8°F (37.1°C)
Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
Urine Protein: 1+
Blood Glucose (fasting): 145 mg/dL
Platelet Count: 140,000/mcL
Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL
Hematocrit: 34%

patient.medicalHistory: Chronic hypertension, well-controlled with medication prior to pregnancy.
